Award.AwardTitle: A Collaborative Leadership Development Workshop for Emerging Leaders in Science and Society; Bainbridge Island, WA - Jaunuary 14-18, 2016

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Complex societal challenges require synthesis of expertise from many academic disciplines and collaboration across multiple institutions. Graduate Ph.D. programs that develop disciplinary experts do not generally provide the context or training for applying narrow expertise in a broader context. This limitation of traditional graduate education programs has created an opportunity to devise programs to prepare PhD students for a range of careers in which STEM expertise is needed for working in broad rather than highly specialized contexts. To address this need and opportunity, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) is piloting a novel model of professional development for graduate students called Emerging Leaders in Science & Society (ELISS), building a network of collaborative STEM leaders by recruiting graduate students from multiple campuses and disciplines to participate in a 15-month service leadership program. These students collaborate with mentors and community leaders to catalyze new connections between the university and broader community and bring relevant research to bear on a timely challenge. This project is supporting the 2016 ELISS Collaborative Leadership Workshop that will introduce the knowledge, skills, and attitudes necessary for collaborative approaches to problems that cross disciplines, institutions, and geographies. This workshop will convene 22 graduate students from seven campuses for a 4.5-day workshop that will build capacity in the context of planning a "think tank" project that will bring relevant research to bear on pressing challenges in their communities. Materials and results of the network will be shared with an ELISS mentor network at participating campuses and through the AAAS network to make collaborative leadership training available to graduate students more broadly.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As the world grows more complex and interconnected, addressing societal challenges will require a workforce with the depth of knowledge, breadth of understanding, and ability to integrate and apply information in different contexts. However, both graduate students and employers complain that their training is too narrow and that they need additional transferrable skills, such as collaboration and communication, to succeed in a number of careers.

To address this need, the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS) developed a service learning opportunity for graduate students, called Emerging Leaders in Science & Society (ELISS). ELISS, an extracurricular program offered at select partner campuses, recruits interdisciplinary teams of graduate students to address a challenge in their community. In 2016, teams from five campuses tackled the question, “How can our communities ensure safe, sustainable, affordable drinking water into the future?”  

This grant enabled all eighteen fellows from the class of 2016, plus a few mentors from previous ELISS classes, to participate in a newly redesigned, Collaborative Leadership Development Workshop from January 14-18, 2016. The goals of the workshop were to build the trust and norms required for good teamwork and to introduce skills and concepts to improve participants’ capacity for leadership, collaboration, and systems thinking.

The agenda featured sessions in team dynamics, recognizing bias, interpersonal communication, leadership styles, stakeholder mapping, strategic planning, and more. The skills were applied directly to the fellows’ drinking water project, and they left with team action plans and specific roles for everyone on the team.

To evaluate the impact of the leadership workshop on collaborative practice, Professor Gary Olson is administering a modified version of the NSF-funded Collaboration Success Wizard, an online survey tool, three times during the year. While the full impact will not be known until after the fellows complete their project, the initial survey showed that the redesigned workshop led to higher collaboration readiness scores than previous years. In responses to a formative evaluation of the workshop, participants were all enthusiastically positive about the experience. Some of their comments follow:

“I loved so much of the workshop, especially the content/modules for leadership, conflict, and diversity. All of these elements are essential for interacting with diverse populations, who may have different interests and levels of influence.”

“[The workshop] allowed us to be vulnerable and let our guard down so we aren't afraid to ask questions or for clarification, or offer a different point of view, etc. I think scientists generally struggle in this area.”

“I thought it was really valuable to share strengths and weaknesses and to take roles that allow us to build new skill sets, not just utilize skills we already feel confident about.”

“It was really helpful to learn about my thinking and conflict management styles, and to push myself outside my comfort zone working on a topic that I am not familiar with.”

“Thank you for making this one of the most productive and enjoyable events I've attended. I learned a lot in such a short time!”

“ELISS has helped me to develop self-reflection, self-awareness, and the belief that I can effect sustainable change in my community.”
